title: Ticket #6855: transfer file transfer plugin along with the job
description:
It should be possible to transfer a file transfer plugin along with a job. This would allow file transfer plugins to be managed on the submit node, or event to be created by advanced users. It would also allow for a much faster development cycle for transfer plugins.

The proposed solution is to add an attribute to the job that specifies the name of the plugin, and the URL tags that that plugin supports. Something like this 

    transfer_plugins = ZKM=/path/to/zkm_plug.exe; HTTP,HTTPS=my_http_plugin.exe

This would add the following to the job. 

    TransferPlugins = "ZKM=/path/to/zkm_plug.exe; HTTP,HTTPS=my_http_plugin.exe"

Then when the job has 

    transfer_input_files = ZKM://myfile,  HTTP://stuff, HTTPS://morestuff

Condor submit would NOT add the ZKM and HTTP file transfer plugin tags to the job's requirements expression, but would instead it would add TARGET.HasJobTransferPlugins to the job's requirements expression. Starters that support file transfer plugins supplied by the job will advertise this attribute.

If there are plugin prefixes in the list of files to be transferred that are not included in the TransferPlugins list, then those plugins would still be added to the job's requirements expression. so 

    transfer_plugins = ZKM=/path/to/zkm_plug.exe; HTTP,HTTPS=my_http_plugin.exe
    transfer_input_files = ZKM://myfile,  HTTP://stuff, HTTPS://morestuff, FTP://file

Would result in a requirements expression that had 

    Requirements = .. && (TARGET.HasJobTransferPlugins && stringListIMember("FTP",TARGET.HasFileTransferPluginMethods))

When the file transfer class is initialized, it will be passed the job ad, so after it loads the transfer plugins from configuration, it will then parse the job's TransferPlugins attribute and add the plugins it finds there to the list of available plugins. Thus plugins transferred by the job will be preferred to plugins available on the execute node.

Because there is no way to indicate whether a plugin is single or multi-file, multi-file will be assumed for plugins transferred with the job.

Plugins transferred with the job will never be run as root.
remarks:
2019-Jan-30 12:30:21 by johnkn:
See the patch file for an implementation. The patch works with the following submit file. The "transfer plugin" in this case is myplug.cmd, which I have verified gets transferred to the execute sandbox and then invoked as a multi-file plugin. 

plug.sub 
executable=simple.bat
transfer_executable=true
transfer_input_files=payload\, simple.in, JMK://foo
Transfer_plugins=JMK:myplug.cmd
arguments = 2
log=plug.log
output=plug.out
error=plug.err
should_transfer_files=yes
when_to_transfer_output=ON_EXIT

queue

I think the patch works when the plugin has an absolute path, but I have not tested that. Also, I know that the file transfer class is used for spooling input files, but I have not tested that case either.

I should have noted in the patch comment, it is for master branch. SHA 3dfdb5dd80988e49ba20feca1a3368fa97dd7e74

2019-Jan-31 08:48:04 by bbockelm:
Code comments are here: https://github.com/htcondor/htcondor/pull/29

The bigger question is about the format of the map itself in the submit language. It's unlike how we do transfer_output_remaps; I'd like to see some consistency between the two.

2019-Jan-31 08:48:46 by bbockelm:
Oh - the other question I had was more general: is there case sensitivity in matching the protocols? Does the HTTP plugin work with a http:// URL?

2019-Jan-31 08:55:40 by johnkn:
URL tags are case-insensitive by definition, although the current file transfer code does this wrong, and treats them as case-sensitive. The matchmaking expression that condor_submit emits in the current code correctly does case-insensitive matchmaking, so we will match an HTTP://file to a STARTD that reports "http" support, which will then fail (sigh). We should fix that, but my patch does not since that would be a much more extensive change.

2019-Jan-31 09:09:52 by johnkn:
I see no value in making it consistent with transfer_output_rempaps, these are entirely different things. On the other hand, swapping the URL tag and the filename and switching from : to = as the separator doesn't really matter either way.

2019-Jan-31 09:53:27 by bbockelm:
Right - I'm not saying that transfer_output_remaps is related, but it's syntactically a list of key-value pairs, just like transfer_plugins is here. We should use the same separators unless there's a strong reason not to.

Can you open a separate ticket for case sensitivity of the protocol schema?

2019-Jan-31 11:54:58 by johnkn:
we should avoid confusing this with transfer_output_remaps unless there is a strong reason treat them as similar.
